option.name: LAST_COMMIT_MESSAGE
option.value: Added observer to take samples of size N, to calculate K_n. The observer outputs occupation numbers in decreasing order, which can be directly used as input to Slatkin's exact test using enumerate.c. This works for SimpleMoran and WrightFisher, but has not been added to the Metapopulation model, since this should be a deme-specific observer and need to think about implementation and output format.

MESSAGE.value: Fully converted to Guice providers, and all unit tests pass (except that I haven't written them to test historical statistics yet). One simple test for multithreaded population dynamics passes, but would be good to engineer more complex tests with additions and subtractions in random order.
Worked out provider issues, and have tag-based adoption counts working (but not yet all the tag-based frequency calculations). Committing so I can experiment a bit in a branch.
Adding README which also serves to outline major design goals

Observer pattern working for monitoring trait and tag statistics via the ITraitDimension abstraction, other observables are possible too.
Also fixed things so that there are separate log4j configurations for production versus test, and there are no paths hardcoded in code, all the config for them is either command line or in the pom.xml (for testing).

The new IPopulation stuff works, and all the agent creation, destruction, and tracking has moved to out of the ISimulationModel implementations. Fixed various issues with Guice injection and model objects need to be singletons. Refactored all unit tests to use IPopulation instead of directly creating agents (an artifact of early dev) so I can detect regression problems. Moving on to other population operations and then population structure, at which point we can have a working WF model.
All tests pass, packaging as jar to use in simple simulations for research proposal.
Fully functional refactoring of madsenlab.org, do not let the GIT commit in IDEA 10 "reformat code" before committing, it does a fine job on Java code but screwed up the Maven pom.xml. Oh well.
Basic interaction topology structure in place, along with a well mixed topology implementation. Ready to do a basic random copying rules implementation
working on basic moran model plus whatever tweaks to dimensions, rules, etc needed to get a simple RCM moran model up and running.

Basic event loop complete for core AbstractSimModel, observer code working in SimpleMoranDriftModel, basic rule architecture there, no decisions on how to abstractly do stacks of rules, so am trying things out in SimpleMoranDriftModel. Ready at this point to do the actual copying and then put in the observation code, recording frequencies to a file etc.

SimpleMoranDriftModel is working, with pure copying and step-by-step frequency recording, for finite numbers of traits and NO mutation yet. But traits drift correctly, and go extinct through drift. Next, I need a mutation rule.

Observers now have a stronger model for per-step and accumulating historical observations, with writing of log files at the end. Seriously improves performance - 10000 agents for 100K steps was 15 seconds. Ready to implement infinite-alleles mutation now, and then move on to heterogeneous rules and statistics.

Basic system in place for providing a properties file for configuring elements of a simulation model like log file locations, and later, database connections. Observers now use this system and a helper class to get a print output stream in the right place with the right name, and don't have to know much of anything about it -- allowing observers to be written to contain mostly *science*, not software engineering boilerplate (a good thing). Not quite happy with directory schemes right now, but it's functional for now, so am tabling the issue until I get more of the rules and tag-based population structure fully working, since that will flush out issues with multiple observers and different types of macro and mesoscopic observables.

Infinite-alleles mutation works on top of basic Moran death-birth dynamics. In this version, log file entries for trait frequencies are held until the end of the run, and then written to a file for performance during simulation. This causes the simulation memory size to _balloon_ significantly - with 10K agents and 50K time steps, the process size grows to 1.02G. The heap size must be adjusted for the parameterization of the model, otherwise GC thrashing causes exponential slowdown towards the end of the simulation. This needs to be addressed, perhaps with a checkpointing architecture, but in general I'm also going to explore HSQLDB as the embedded data collection system.
Added top-level docs directory, and did a Javadoc run, since it's handy while developing to have my own API docs. Other directories will have design documents and notes on experiments.

Basic structure of metapopulation model in place, simplified structure of simulation files separate from library. Also fixed a problem where simulation *and* copying were happening in the same elemental time step. The system now has a "subrule" framework, and each agent now fires a "CopyOrMutateDecisionRule" which decides which thing will happen in a given time step, and then calls the appropriate subrule (which can be a stack of rules...). This has not been merged into the master yet, will wait until the rest of the bugs in metapopulation are fixed....

Fixed the tag-based frequency-counting problem here, it's now producing frequency output for each deme. I forget things like tag.registerAgent() -- the oldest parts of the API. Now can move on to implementing some migration or otherwise handling inter-deme communication.

1. Updated copyright 2. Created IActionRule base interface, to separate Interaction rules from Observation rules, to handle agent-to-agent, versus agent-with-artifact, forms of information flow. Verified that simple moran drift still works properly after this refactoring. 3. Started creation of interfaces and utilities for artifacts, artifact collections, and artifact tags, in support of creating simulations with pools of artifacts that are created, destroyed, and observed by individuals.

Added basic mean-field Wright-Fisher model, refactored the setting of log4j configuration so that simulation logs are written to per-file directories, made all existing models consistent with that. Wright-Fisher is unverified at this point for correct quantitative properties and is not yet usable for research. But close -- need to add some observations, verify its properties. And I need to do something about the file-based trait count/freq stuff since the in-memory storage of history slows things down, but flushing to files slows it down even more. These two things are left, and then it's ready for production use.

Still a bug in WF - the sum total of trait counts does not add up to the population size, which is a crucial check on whether traits self-count properly (since we never "sweep" the population, these are truly independent pieces of information). On the other hand, Observers have been moved to the TraitDimension, from traits themselves, which firstly cuts down on redundant calls to notify, and allows many copying events to happen in a single time step as in WF, and then the notifyObservers() call is made at the end of each model step. This is *equivalent* to the former functionality for Moran-style models, since only one agent has rules fired in any given step. All of this is working, and the SimpleMoran and Metapopulation models look good at first glance through logs (Moran accurately counts). Just need to find the bug in WF, and possibly establish an "old" and "new" population abstraction, so that we freeze a view of the population for a single WF step to work with, and then advance it.

Implemented "sampling with replacement" for Wright-Fisher models by introducing a TraitCopyingType which allows the model to snapshot the population state at the beginning of a time step, use that for sampling traits to copy, and building up the new population state. Also did a JProfiler run to get a sense of where memory is going, and it's overwhelmingly going to holding millions of Integer objects. Might be time to refactor that to primitive ints. Still not verified on Wright-Fisher but getting close.

Bug in trait counting fixed -- trait ID's were being assigned with model tick numbers, so in Moran they were always unique, but WF multiple traits with the same ID were created each tick. This has been fixed, and a direct census of the population now matches the Observer-based trait counting, so the latter is trustworthy and can continue to be used. Performance is also extremely good -- with 1000 agents, and 1000 copying events per agent (1000 ticks for WF, 1M ticks for Moran), both models run in under 60 seconds, and the WF model runs in less than 30. That's outstanding compared to old TransmissionLab times. The model is ready for the final few time-averaging and Ewens sampling features needed for SAA 2012 paper.

VERIFIED correct behavior on Wright-Fisher and Moran models. Given population scaling of N (rather than 2N), the mean number of variants expected is N * mu * <lifetime> where lifetime is in units of N copying events. The values are nearly exact in both models. There is a configurable parameter to not record statistics until a specified model tick, to get past transient initial behavior given random assignment of traits in the population. This seems to work nicely at 10% of the population size in time units of N copying events (i.e., at least generation 100 in WF for 1000 individuals, or 100K ticks for 1000 individuals in Moran).
Added summary descriptive statistics on trait counts K_pop, and trait lifetime (total sojourn time? not sure what this is canonically called -- Gale's "g").
This is ready for any analysis that uses synchronic data, or can post-process the raw counts.

VERIFIED correct behavior on Wright-Fisher and Moran models. Given population scaling of N (rather than 2N), the mean number of variants expected is N * mu * <lifetime> where lifetime is in units of N copying events. The values are nearly exact in both models. There is a configurable parameter to not record statistics until a specified model tick, to get past transient initial behavior given random assignment of traits in the population. This seems to work nicely at 10% of the population size in time units of N copying events (i.e., at least generation 100 in WF for 1000 individuals, or 100K ticks for 1000 individuals in Moran). Added summary descriptive statistics on trait counts K_pop, and trait lifetime (total sojourn time? not sure what this is canonically called -- Gale's "g"). This is ready for any analysis that uses synchronic data, or can post-process the raw counts.

Added observer to take samples of size N, to calculate K_n. The observer outputs occupation numbers in decreasing order, which can be directly used as input to Slatkin's exact test using enumerate.c. This works for SimpleMoran and WrightFisher, but has not been added to the Metapopulation model, since this should be a deme-specific observer and need to think about implementation and output format.
